thread.title: Portland votes again on marijuana regulations, protects existing shops
thread.title_full: Portland votes again on marijuana regulations, protects existing shops | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Theen | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Portland votes again on marijuana regulations, protects existing shops
text:
Portland approved changes to its marijuana regulations Wednesday, granting more protections to existing medical shops that hope to expand into the recreational business world.
The City Council first approved pot rules on Sept. 30, but said officials would revisit the regulations at the request of industry leaders who said the city didn't do enough to protect businesses that've already navigated the state's bureaucracy and successfully opened dispensaries.
The new rules give those businesses the first chance to apply for recreational marijuana licenses and exempts the stores from rules that prohibit pot stores from opening within 1,000 feet of each other.
Related : Read more about those regulations here , including when businesses would be protected, here.
Commissioner Dan Saltzman, who introduced the failed plan to waive the 1,000-foot buffer rules downtown to encourage more marijuana stores, was the only City Council member to oppose the new rules.
"I'm convinced we don't need two layers of regulatory authority," Saltzman said, citing the state's liquor control commission. Portland could spend an estimated $1 million annually to monitor and license the industry.
"It's regulatory overkill," Saltzman said.
Portland will begin accepting applications for recreational marijuana licenses on Dec. 1, but those businesses aren't expected to open until late 2016.
